"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>上<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>above, up</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Ground, Toe</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">There's a <font color=""#0af""><b>toe</b></font> <font color=""#f0a""><b>above</b></font> <font color=""#0af""><b>ground</b></font>. Look at it.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Why is this important? There's another kanji with the toe below the ground, and I bet you can guess the meaning of that kanji. So, where's the toe? It's above the ground. Remember, the toe is what's important here (and its location, because you have to find it otherwise they won't be able to sew it back on).</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>下<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>below</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Ground, Toe</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">There's a <font color=""#0af""><b>toe</b></font> <font color=""#f0a""><b>below</b></font> <font color=""#0af""><b>ground</b></font>.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: So, where is the <font color=""#0af""><b>toe</b></font> now? It's <font color=""#f0a""><b>below</b></font> ground. Imagine yourself digging it out, and thinking... ugh, why does it have to be <font color=""#f0a""><b>below</b></font> ground like this? So irritating. Will I be able to sew it back on in time to save it?</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>大<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>big</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Big</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>big</b></font> radical and the <font color=""#f0a""><b>big</b></font> kanji are exactly the same!</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: So, if you know the radical, you know the meaning of this kanji as well.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>八<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>eight</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Fins</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">This isn't exactly the same as the <font color=""#0af""><b>fins</b></font> radical, but it's close. Sometimes this will happen (where we have to use a slightly 'modified radical' version of the original), so it's good to understand that now, early on. In this case, we have fins. How many fins? <font color=""#f0a""><b>eight</b></font> fins. How do you know that? Because you caught four fish with two fins each.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Count the fins out in front of you, all the way from one to eight. It'll help if you actually do this. Now smell each fin, and think 'wow, I have to smell all eight of these?' Yes, you do.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>入<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>enter</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Enter</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <font color=""#0af""><b>enter</b></font> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <font color=""#f0a""><b>enter</b></font> as well.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Make sure you know those radicals, yo!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>工<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>construction, industry</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Construction</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The radical is <font color=""#0af""><b>construction</b></font>, which is part of the construction <font color=""#f0a""><b>industry</b></font>.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Not to mention, <font color=""#0af""><b>construction</b></font> of buildings and factories leads to all kinds of new <font color=""#f0a""><b>industries</b></font> as well. Think of all the new industries you could build with construction!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>山<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>mountain</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Mountain</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>mountain</b></font> radical and the <font color=""#f0a""><b>mountain</b></font> kanji are the same.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Make sure you're studying your radicals. If you are, then you're studying your kanji as well!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>口<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>mouth</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Mouth</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both <font color=""#f0a""><b>mouth</b></font>.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: As long as you know the radical <font color=""#0af""><b>mouth</b></font> you know the kanji <font color=""#f0a""><b>mouth</b></font>.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>九<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>nine</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Nine</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Nice! This kanji is the same as the radical that looks just like it (down to the meaning, even!). The radical is <font color=""#0af""><b>Nine</b></font> and the kanji is <font color=""#f0a""><b>Nine</b></font> making the meaning of this kanji really easy to remember as long as you know the radical first.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: If you know the radicals nice and well, you'll know this kanji's meaning nice and well too!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>一<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>one</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Ground</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Lying on the <font color=""#0af""><b>ground</b></font> is something that looks just like the ground, the number <font color=""#f0a""><b>One</b></font>. Why is this One lying down? It's been shot by the number two. It's lying there, bleeding out and dying. The number One doesn't have long to live.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: To remember the meaning of <font color=""#f0a""><b>One</b></font>, imagine yourself there at the scene of the crime. You grab <font color=""#f0a""><b>One</b></font> in your arms, trying to prop it up, trying to hear its last words. Instead, it just splatters some blood on your face. 'Who did this to you?' you ask. The number One points weakly, and you see number Two running off into an alleyway. He's always been jealous of number One and knows he can be number one now that he's taken the real number one out.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>人<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>person</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Person</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Do you remember the radical version of this kanji, where you knocked a zombie down breaking it in half, only leaving its legs standing? Then it said 'Hey, I'm a <font color=""#0af""><b>Person</b></font> too?' Well, that radical is a kanji too, and that kanji is <font color=""#f0a""><b>Person</b></font>.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Know the radicals, and you shall know the kanji.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>力<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>power</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Power</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The radical and the meaning of this kanji are the same. Both are <font color=""#f0a""><b>Power</b></font>.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: If you know the radicals, you should be feeling fine... No, you should feel powerful!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>川<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>river</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">River</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>river</b></font> radical and the <font color=""#f0a""><b>river</b></font> kanji are the same as each other!</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: So, if you know the radical you know the kanji as well.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>七<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>seven</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Seven</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Lucky for you (as is the case with many of the lower-stroke kanji), this kanji is the same as the radical you've already learned. The radical that makes up this kanji is <font color=""#0af""><b>seven</b></font> and the kanji (which is exactly the same) is also <font color=""#f0a""><b>seven</b></font>. So, if you know the radical, you know the meaning of the kanji as well.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Make sure you know your radicals well and you'll be A-Okay on this one!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>十<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>ten</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Cross</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">When you think of <font color=""#0af""><b>cross</b></font>es, you think of certain religions (Christianity). Instead of thinking about Christianity, though, let's think about where the Christians came from, namely the Jewish faith. How many commandments did they have? They had <font color=""#f0a""><b>ten</b></font> of them.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: This kanji is made up entirely of the <font color=""#0af""><b>cross</b></font> radical, which might be a little confusing since you have to remember two different meanings. If you make a progression of the story in your mind, though, it should be a lot better. So, as long as you think 'Okay, I have a cross ... what have I associated with this cross? Why, the <font color=""#f0a""><b>Ten</b></font> Commandments.' If you do this, you should be alright and you should be able to remember both!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>三<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>three</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Ground, Two</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">This one uses the ground radical (which also happens to be the kanji for 'one') and the radical 'two.' Let's combine those ones together. What do you get? You get <font color=""#f0a""><b>three</b></font>.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: This one should be pretty self explanatory! Even easier, you can look at this kanji and see it has three straight lines. You know what one looks like. You know what two looks like. So... this is three! (Four is not like this, though).</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>二<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>two</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Two</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The kanji <font color=""#f0a""><b>two</b></font> and the radical <font color=""#0af""><b>two</b></font> are the exact same things. Therefore, you know the kanji for two already!</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: More simply put, you can just know that this kanji is the double of One. It's two lines, that's not all that hard to remember!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>女<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>woman</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Woman</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The radical for <font color=""#0af""><b>woman</b></font> and the kanji for <font color=""#f0a""><b>woman</b></font> are exactly the same.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: That means if you know your radicals well, you know the meaning of this kanji as well! How swell.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>又<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>again</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Stool</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">You're sitting on your <font color=""#0af""><b>stool</b></font> <font color=""#f0a""><b>again</b></font>!!?</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: There's someone you know who carries a stool around with her all the time. Why? Because she's super pregnant and can't walk too far. You're walking with her, but she has to stop every few feet and sit on her stool, again and <font color=""#f0a""><b>again</b></font>. Feel irritated about this, because it will help you to remember the meaning of this kanji better. Imagine this scene taking place several times as you're trying to walk to your destination together, but she's too slow and it's super-duper irritating.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>玉<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>ball</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Drop, King</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>king</b></font> has something in his hand that he's <b><font color=""#0af"">drop</font></b>ping... but it bounces too! He's bouncing a <font color=""#f0a""><b>ball.</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: This kanji looks just like a king bouncing a <font color=""#f0a""><b>ball</b></font>, no? If not, imagine the kanji itself bouncing the drop (the <font color=""#f0a""><b>ball</b></font>) over and over again, then laying some hoops like a pro.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>本<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>book, origin, real, main</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Real</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>real</b></font> radical and the <font color=""#f0a""><b>book</b></font> kanji are the same in looks, but different in meaning. Still, what's the most real thing in the world, besides real life? That would be a book. People put their heart and soul into books, making them as real as they can... that is, unless you read Twilight. There's nothing real about glittery vampires.<br>Take note that the second, third, and fourth meanings of this kanji are <font color=""#f0a""><b>origin</b></font>, <font color=""#f0a""><b>real</b></font>, and <font color=""#f0a""><b>main</b></font>. You can figure this out by thinking about how books almost always have their <font color=""#f0a""><b>origin</b></font> in <font color=""#f0a""><b>real</b></font> life. This in fact is the <font color=""#f0a""><b>main</b></font> source of book materials (real life).</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine yourself reading various books... and have them have crazy contents. Constantly think... 'Is it <font color=""#0af""><b>real</b></font>?' And then decide. Focus in on the fact you're reading a <font color=""#f0a""><b>book</b></font>, especially.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>子<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>child</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Child</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>child</b></font> radical and the <font color=""#f0a""><b>child</b></font> kanji are exactly the same.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: So, if you know your radicals, you know your kanji as well! This won't last forever (where radicals are exactly the same as the kanji) so enjoy it while the kanji are still small and simple!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>丸<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>circle</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Drop, Nine</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">What's something with <font color=""#0af""><b>nine</b></font> sides? Just add a <font color=""#0af""><b>drop</b></font> and you'll have something that's almost a <font color=""#f0a""><b>circle</b></font>.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: It's not quite a <font color=""#f0a""><b>circle</b></font> though. You just need to add a <font color=""#0af""><b>drop</b></font> of liquid to the edges to smooth it out to become a full circle.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>正<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>correct</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Ground, Stop</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">What <font color=""#0af""><b>ground</b></font> to a <font color=""#0af""><b>stop</b></font>, so to speak? You're working on grading tests. But, you run into a question that is wrong, which made you stop. Why? Because you have to <font color=""#f0a""><b>correct</b></font> it.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Go ahead and correct several answers. Feel like you suddenly have to stop whenever you have to correct something. Ugh, how time consuming.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>犬<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>dog</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Dog</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>dog</b></font> radical and <font color=""#f0a""><b>dog</b></font> kanji are exactly the same!</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Soon there will be very few kanji/radical-same combos ... so enjoy it while you can.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>夕<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>evening</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Evening</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>evening</b></font> radical and the <font color=""#f0a""><b>evening</b></font> kanji are exactly the same.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: So, if you know the radical, you know the meaning of this kanji as well. Make sure you know your radicals - they're the building block of everything you learn here!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>出<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>exit</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Mountain</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">There are two <font color=""#0af""><b>mountains</b></font> in front of you... and probably a bunch more around you too. You are in a pass, and don't know how to get out. You are frantically looking for the <font color=""#f0a""><b>exit</b></font> before you freeze to death. The most important thing is to find the exit from this mountain range - your life depends on it.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: In your imagination, really feel like your life depends on getting out. The important part is the feeling of 'needing to get out of the mountain pass.' If you have this feeling, you'll be more likely to remember that this kanji means exit, because that's what you want to do when you see this kanji.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>目<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>eye</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Eye</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>eye</b></font> radical and <font color=""#f0a""><b>eye</b></font> kanji are the same as each other, so now you know them both.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Well... you'll know them both as long as you studied your radicals, young grasshopper. If you didn't, then you're just a young grasshopper who needs to study his/her radicals.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>了<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>finish</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Barb</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Think about it this way. There is a famous fishing lure inventor, working on his best work ever. He’s old, and he’s been trying to make the best fishing lure for the last 50 years, and knows this will be his last invention. Then he figures it out. He takes one <font color=""#0af""><b>barb</b></font>, and connects the end of it to the top of another <font color=""#0af""><b>barb</b></font>. When he does this, he knows his work is finally <font color=""#f0a""><b>finish</b></font>ed.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Make sure you look at this amazing fishing lure too - hold it in your hand, see the two barbs fused together. Think about how strange this lure is. Is this really the best in the world? Will this really finish all other fishing lures?</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>火<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>fire</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Fire</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>fire</b></font> and the <font color=""#f0a""><b>fire</b></font> kanji are the same as each other.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: If you know the radicals then this one is EZPZ.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>五<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>five</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Five</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The radical and the kanji are the same, so make sure you know the radical to know the meaning of this kanji as well (<font color=""#f0a""><b>five</b></font>).</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Know your radicals, friend-o.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>四<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>four</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Mouth, Legs</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Imagine contorting yourself in such a way that your <font color=""#0af""><b>legs</b></font> end up inside your <font color=""#0af""><b>mouth</b></font>. You have bent your body in all the wrong ways in order to achieve this. In fact, if you look at yourself, you look like a square now... You're just a person with <font color=""#f0a""><b>four</b></font> sides.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: If you can get to square, you should be able to get to four as well, since squares always have <font color=""#f0a""><b>four</b></font> sides.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>才<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>genius</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Cross, Slide</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">You have a <font color=""#0af""><b>cross</b></font>. Why is there a <font color=""#0af""><b>slide</b></font> / stroke going through the cross? Why, because religion really was a 'stroke of <font color=""#f0a""><b>genius</b></font>.'&nbsp;Oh, and see that little hook at the bottom? That's because once they hook onto you, they never let go. More genius!</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: When you think about crosses and religion, it's hard to help but think of how it's changed and affected history. Someone was pretty <font color=""#f0a""><b>genius</b></font> at some point.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>手<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>hand</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Hand</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>hand</b></font> radical and the <font color=""#f0a""><b>hand</b></font> kanji are identical in looks and meaning! That should make things easy!</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Make sure you're studying your radicals. It won't be forever that radicals and kanji overlap so nicely like this!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>天<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>heaven</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Heaven</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The radical <font color=""#0af""><b>heaven</b></font> is the same as the kanji <font color=""#f0a""><b>heaven</b></font>, making this an easy kanji to memorize.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: If you know your radicals well (and you should!) you know the meaning of this kanji well, as well!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>刀<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>sword</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Sword</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The radical and the meaning of this kanji are almost the same, but not quite. It's very easy, though - the radical is <font color=""#0af""><b>sword</b></font>. We're learning Japanese, so can you name a Japanese sword. That's right, the most common is a <font color=""#f0a""><b>katana</b></font>, which happens to be the meaning of this kanji as well.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: The progression on this one is important. When you think sword you have to think 'what kinds of swords do Japanese people have?' Then, you'll reach the meaning of this kanji on your own.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>王<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>king</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">King</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#f0a""><b>king</b></font> kanji and the <font color=""#0af""><b>king</b></font> radical are the same!</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Hopefully you're a <font color=""#f0a""><b>king</b></font> of radicals... because if you are, this kanji meaning was super easy for you!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>左<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>left</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Construction, Narwhal</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>Narwhal</b></font> <font color=""#0af""><b>construction</b></font> group wants to build houses for narwhals. Instead of speaking for the narwhals like the right (右) does, they take action and build houses for narwhals that need homes. These people are members of the <font color=""#f0a""><b>left</b></font>, liberal political party. Of course, they're using lots of high taxes to pay for these houses, which the right doesn't like. That's how you know the <font color=""#f0a""><b>left</b></font> is involved in the construction.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine a bunch of hippies building the houses. That's how you'll know they're the liberal group, and on the <font color=""#f0a""><b>left</b></font>.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>中<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>middle, inside</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Middle</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The radical <font color=""#0af""><b>Middle</b></font> and the kanji <font color=""#f0a""><b>Middle</b></font> are both the same. So if you know one, you know the other.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Make sure you're studying your radicals, otherwise you might find yourself in the middle of a kanji-learning problem.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>月<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>moon</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Moon</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#f0a""><b>moon</b></font> kanji is made up of the <font color=""#0af""><b>moon</b></font> radical.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: This should be EZPZ as long as you know the radicals already!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>々<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>repeater</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Drop, Enclosure</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">This is a strange kanji because it doesn't really mean anything at all. In fact, what it does is it repeats the kanji that comes before it. For example: 人々 is actually 人人. This kanji shows up whenever there's a repeating kanji, because it's often easier to write than writing a more complicated kanji twice. That's why this kanji is the <font color=""#f0a""><b>repeater</b></font>. It repeats what comes before it.<br>To remember that this kanji is the repeater, though, think of a <font color=""#0af""><b>drop</b></font> going into an <font color=""#0af""><b>enclosure</b></font>. Drip drop drip drop. It does that over and over again even after it fills up. The dropping of the drops is the repeater portion.</span></span></span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Since this kanji doesn't really have a meaning as much as it does a function, try to change the way you think about it when you're memorizing it.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>田<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>rice paddy</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Rice Paddy</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>rice paddy</b></font> radical and the <font color=""#f0a""><b>rice paddy</b></font> kanji are the same, making this one super easy to remember, at least meaning-wise.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Just know your radicals, and you will know your kanji as well.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>右<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>right</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Mouth, Narwhal</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>Narwhal</b></font> <font color=""#0af""><b>mouths</b></font>. These are a group of people who speak on behalf of the narwhals. Strangely, though, in terms of political party, it's the <font color=""#f0a""><b>right</b></font> that's representing these majestic animals.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: The <font color=""#f0a""><b>right</b></font> are protesting gun rights and lower taxes for narwhals. Make sure you think it's strange that the <font color=""#f0a""><b>right</b></font> would even ask for these things for narwhals, let alone try to represent the narwhals... something's fishy here.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>六<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>six</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Fins, Lid</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Just imagine a beast with a <font color=""#0af""><b>lid</b></font> for a head and <font color=""#0af""><b>fins</b></font> for feet, running around looking as insane as possible (really imagine it!). When it runs up to you, it shows you the top of its lid-head. On it is written the numbers 666. Why? Because it's a spawn of the devil, and the number <font color=""#f0a""><b>six</b></font> is the devil's number.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine this beast doing various crazy things, the crazier the better (to help you remember). Make sure all these things are associated with the devil and the devil's number (<font color=""#f0a""><b>six</b></font>), so you can remember the meaning of this kanji.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>小<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>small</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Small</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>small</b></font> radical and the <font color=""#f0a""><b>small</b></font> kanji are exactly the same.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: So, know the radicals and you'll know the kanji. Nice how that works out.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>土<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>soil</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Grave</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The radical <font color=""#0af""><b>grave</b></font> makes up the entirety of this kanji. In a grave, it's filled in with one thing, <font color=""#f0a""><b>soil</b></font>.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine yourself filling up a grave, shoveling in shovelfuls of <font color=""#f0a""><b>soil</b></font>. It's sad business, especially since you're burying someone/something really important to you :( In your imagination, smell the soil that you're scooping in. Touch it and feel it too. Using more of your senses (even in your imagination) will help you to remember the meaning of this kanji (and any kanji) more effectively.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>立<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>stand</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Stand</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The radical <font color=""#0af""><b>stand</b></font> and the kanji <font color=""#f0a""><b>stand</b></font> are the same thing, so now you know them both.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: If you're keeping up with your radical studies, you're also keeping up with your kanji studies!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>石<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>stone</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Stone</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>stone</b></font> radical and <font color=""#f0a""><b>stone</b></font> kanji are the same thing!</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Know your radicals and therefore know your kanji. It's just that simple.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>丁<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>street, ward</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Nail</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">This kanji is made up of the <font color=""#0af""><b>nail</b></font> radical. Where would you hate to see nails? The worst place to scatter nails would be the <font color=""#f0a""><b>street</b></font> because of all the cars driving by.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine someone spreading nails out all over the street and watching cars hitting them and popping all the tires. Who would do such a terrible thing?</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>日<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>sun, day</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Sun</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>sun</b></font> radical and <font color=""#f0a""><b>sun</b></font> kanji are the same, huzzah! Also, if you want to remember <font color=""#f0a""><b>day</b></font> as well, you can just think about how a day is the time it takes for the sun to cross the sky.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: The radical for this one is easy too, making the meaning for this kanji super easy as well!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>千<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>thousand</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Thousand</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">This kanji looks like and means the same thing as the radical, which makes it particularly easy to remember.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: As long as you know the radical <font color=""#0af""><b>thousand</b></font> then you know the kanji <font color=""#f0a""><b>thousand</b></font> as well!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>木<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>tree, wood</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Tree</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">This is another kanji that is the same as the radical. Both <font color=""#0af""><b>tree</b></font> and <font color=""#f0a""><b>tree</b></font> are the same in looks and meaning.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: So, how are those radicals doing? Do you know them well?</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>水<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>water</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Water</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>water</b></font> radical and the <font color=""#f0a""><b>water</b></font> kanji are the same.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: So as long as you know the radicals, you know the kanji.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>白<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>white</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">White</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The radical <font color=""#0af""><b>white</b></font> and the kanji <font color=""#f0a""><b>white</b></font> are the same.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Study your radicals hard! Most important thing!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>文<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>writing</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Doll</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>doll</b></font> means <font color=""#f0a""><b>writing</b></font>. This is one of those rare instances where the kanji and the radical meanings don't match (even though they look the same).<br>To remember this one, Imagine a doll walking around. It's evil, obviously. You don't see it walking around, but you know it is. You keep finding nasty notes... <font color=""#f0a""><b>writing</b></font> that she has done while you're asleep, telling you nasty things and threatening you.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Feel the fear of this as if it were actually happening. <font color=""#f0a""><b>Writing</b></font>? From a doll?? Imagine the things she could write to you and be afraid. Dolls really are terrifying.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>円<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>yen, round</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Lid, Head</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The combination of radicals for this kanji may not be obvious at first, but if you look carefully you'll see it. The <font color=""#0af""><b>lid</b></font> is inside the <font color=""#0af""><b>head</b></font> for this kanji because it's holding something in. Imagine the top of someone's head being closed by a lid. Open that lid up and peer inside... it's full of <font color=""#f0a""><b>yen</b></font> coins, the Japanese money system.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Another thing that will help is to associate the word <font color=""#f0a""><b>round</b></font> to this kanji, because it has both of these meanings. Both are right, and if you learn one that's better than not learning either, but maybe if you think about how <font color=""#f0a""><b>round</b></font> the coins themselves are inside this person's head, you'll remember this one too.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>矢<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>arrow</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Arrow</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>arrow</b></font> radical and the <font color=""#f0a""><b>arrow</b></font> kanji are the same. Sort of a 'straight' shot to memorizing this kanji, you know?</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Just know your radicals and you'll know this kanji!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>市<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>city</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Lid, Two Face</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">That mean guy <b><font color=""#0af"">Two-face</font></b> is trying to hide from Batman by wearing a <b><font color=""#0af"">lid</font></b> over his face. The problem is, everyone in the whole <b><font color=""#f0a"">city</font></b> recognizes him. No one else would even try wearing a lid.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Picture the big <b><font color=""#f0a"">city</font></b> so full of people and, oh, nope that's definitely Two-face wearing a lid. He's so obvious even in a city this big. Go get him, Batman.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>牛<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>cow</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Cow</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The radical and the kanji for <font color=""#f0a""><b>cow</b></font> are exactly the same! That makes it easy to remember, so long as you know your radicals well enough.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: The radicals are important to know, so make sure you're studying them. They'll come back again, you know!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>切<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>cut</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Seven, Sword</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">If you have <font color=""#0af""><b>seven</b></font> <font color=""#0af""><b>swords</b></font>, there's only so much you can do with them. The main thing? Probably using them to <font color=""#f0a""><b>cut</b></font> something.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Take these seven swords and swing them around. <font color=""#f0a""><b>Cut</b></font> everything in your path, including yourself. Then, think about how dumb it was to try to use seven swords at once, and then feel the pain of the cut you gave yourself. Ouch, ouch ouch.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>方<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>direction, way</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Direction</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The radical and the kanji for <font color=""#f0a""><b>direction</b></font> are the same! Huzzah!<br>There is also another meaning too, though. This can also mean <font color=""#f0a""><b>way</b></font> as well. Think of it this way: When you move in one direction in your life, you are developing your own <font color=""#f0a""><b>way</b></font>. 'The way of [your name here].'</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: The only <font color=""#f0a""><b>direction</b></font> you need to go in is forward, as long as you know the radicals enough to know the meaning of this kanji, too.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>戸<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>door</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Door</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The radical and the kanji for <font color=""#f0a""><b>door</b></font> are the same!</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Time to open the door to the reading part of this mnemonic.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>太<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>fat</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Big, Drop</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">You have a <font color=""#0af""><b>big</b></font> guy here, with an extra <font color=""#0af""><b>drop</b></font> of something below his thigh, hanging down. That's <font color=""#f0a""><b>fat</b></font> right there. He's so fat he has things of fat hanging off his fat.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Maybe you should touch the <font color=""#f0a""><b>fat</b></font> below his leg just to see what it is... feel it, and squeeze it. It'll help you to remember that this kanji means 'fat.'</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>父<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>father</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Father</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The radical and the kanji for <font color=""#f0a""><b>father</b></font> are the same.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: No, I am not your father... but this kanji / radical set is!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>少<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>few, a little</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Slide, Small</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">You have a <font color=""#0af""><b>small</b></font> <font color=""#0af""><b>slide</b></font>. The thing about small slides is that they can only fit a <font color=""#f0a""><b>few</b></font> people at a time.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine a small slide (how could you not, after you see the radicals?) with only a few people on it, trying to move forward. Only a few people are required to create a slide traffic jam, though :(</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>友<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>friend</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Narwhal, Stool</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>narwhal</b></font> is sitting on a <font color=""#0af""><b>stool</b></font>. Why is he sitting there? You told all the people you thought were your <font color=""#f0a""><b>friends</b></font> to stay sitting on the stools if they were indeed still your friend. When you come back to see who's still left, it turns out only the narwhal is there for you. Narwhals make the greatest of friends.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine the narwhal saying 'Hey buddy, I'm still your <font color=""#f0a""><b>friend</b></font>,' and then jumping over to you to give you a nice narwhal hug. You cry, because you're relieved you have at least one friend left, even if it is a narwhal.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>毛<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>fur, hair</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Fur</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text""><font color=""#f0a""><b>Fur</b></font> and <font color=""#0af""><b>fur</b></font> are the same as each other, so the meaning of this kanji should be simple. This can also mean <font color=""#f0a""><b>hair</b></font>, too, though more like furry hair.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Just make sure you're studying your radicals, otherwise it won't be as simple as I'd hoped.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>半<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>half</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Antenna, Triceratops</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">There's a <font color=""#0af""><b>triceratops</b></font> on top of the <font color=""#0af""><b>antenna</b></font>... which is a problem, because when he's there, you only get <font color=""#f0a""><b>half</b></font> of the channels on your TV.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Be irritated as you go through your channels. Literally every other one (<font color=""#f0a""><b>half</b></font> of them) are just static. CHSHHHHH! Maybe you go up to your roof and push the triceratops off the antenna to fix it. When you come back down, strangely the other half of the channels work, but the original half are broken, now... Be a little angry about this, and mostly focus your anger on the half thing, not the triceratops thing.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>心<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>heart</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Heart</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The radical <font color=""#0af""><b>heart</b></font> and the kanji <font color=""#f0a""><b>heart</b></font> are the same. Rejoice and let your heart be free!</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Also, make sure you know the radicals by heart, it'll help you to learn more effectively, just like with this kanji.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>内<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>inside</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Person, Head</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">There's a <font color=""#0af""><b>person</b></font> <font color=""#f0a""><b>inside</b></font> your <font color=""#0af""><b>head</b></font>.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: And, you have no idea how to get them out. They're <font color=""#f0a""><b>inside</b></font> for good, and it's freaking you out. As in, there's a little person in there, running around, controlling your brain. People think you're crazy, but you know better... He's <font color=""#f0a""><b>inside</b></font> there, doing evil things.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>生<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>life</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Life</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>life</b></font> radical and the life kanji are the same, so hopefully you now just know them both.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Study your radicals and you'll read good.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>久<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>long time</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Raptor Cage</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>raptor cage</b></font> is a reinforced enclosure, so it will hold those raptors in for a really <font color=""#f0a""><b>long time</b></font>.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: You've seen Jurassic Park, though. You know this isn't true... Be suspicious of whoever's telling you this.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>台<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>machine</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Mouth, Pile</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">There's a <font color=""#0af""><b>pile</b></font> of stuff that's going to be put inside your <font color=""#0af""><b>mouth</b></font>... and it is terrible stuff. There's cars, microwave ovens, televisions, and more, and somehow you have to put them all in your mouth. This is some kind of torture, so feel the fear of what you're about to go through. The reason you want to imagine these things going into your mouth in particular is because these things are machines, and this is the <font color=""#f0a""><b>machine</b></font> counter kanji that you're learning.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: If you need extra help remembering, you'll have to imagine these big <font color=""#f0a""><b>machines</b></font> being put into your mouth, stretching your cheeks out huge and filling it up. This is the most painful thing ever, but somehow you're able to put this pile of machines in your mouth... you'll live another day.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>母<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>mother</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Drawer</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>drawer</b></font> radical looks like the <font color=""#f0a""><b>mother</b></font> kanji, though their meanings are different. Still, this isn't too far of a stretch. Who's the nice person that folds and puts your clothes in your drawer? That's your mother.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: On the other hand, you can imagine your <font color=""#f0a""><b>mother</b></font> yelling at you to put your clothes away in your <font color=""#0af""><b>drawers</b></font> as well. Either way, just make sure your mother is involved in this mnemonic.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>午<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>noon</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Slide, Antenna</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>antenna</b></font>&nbsp;picks up your favorite show about <font color=""#0af""><b>slides</b></font> every day at <font color=""#f0a""><b>noon</b></font>.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: You know this because at noon you're always busy eating lunch, and you can't watch the awesome reality slide television show that you so want to watch more than anything! Make sure you feel this way in your heart (at least in your imagination) because it will help you to remember that this kanji means noon, because noon is when your 'slides-show' comes on the TV via the antenna.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>北<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>north</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Spoon, Nailbat</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>nailbat</b></font> and <font color=""#0af""><b>spoon</b></font> are your weapons (what else would you do with a nailbat and spoon combination? Prolly nothing). What will you do with these things? You're going up to the <font color=""#f0a""><b>North</b></font> Pole to take out that two-timing, scheming bearded elf slave-driver named Santa.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: If you need help, think that you'll use the <font color=""#0af""><b>nailbat</b></font> to take out Santa, and the <font color=""#0af""><b>spoon</b></font> to dig a grave and bury him. Things might get kinda graphic in your head, but just know that it's for the sake of memorization, and even Santa has to make sacrifices some time. Also, focus on the location as well. You know that Santa is at the <font color=""#f0a""><b>North</b></font> Pole. Think about how that's where you need to go to finish your job.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>今<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>now</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Ra, Hat</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">We theoretically have the Egyptian God <font color=""#0af""><b>Ra</b></font> wearing a <font color=""#0af""><b>hat</b></font> to help us to remember this kanji. Just think about this God, wearing a silly hat... maybe one of those ones with a propeller. He takes off his hat and wants someone to take it from him right <font color=""#f0a""><b>NOW</b></font>.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: He is an incredibly impatient God. That is something you'll have to remember when thinking about this, because impatient gods want things done right <font color=""#f0a""><b>NOW</b></font>!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>古<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>old</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Old</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>old</b></font> radical and the <font color=""#f0a""><b>old</b></font> kanji are one and the same, which means you know them both.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Know your radicals, and you will know your kanji.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>兄<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>older brother</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Mouth, Legs</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Who's someone who's just a <font color=""#0af""><b>mouth</b></font> with <font color=""#0af""><b>legs</b></font>? That's your know-it-all <font color=""#f0a""><b>older brother</b></font>, who won't shut up about anything.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: To help this mnemonic along, literally imagine your <font color=""#f0a""><b>older brother</b></font> as someone that's just a giant mouth with a pair of legs walking it around. It talks and talks and talks, too, irritating you. Feel the irritation specifically at your older brother. He's older than you, so you can't beat him up... yet.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>元<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>origin</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Origin</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The radical and the kanji are the same! You're in luck, today.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: As long as you know your radicals, you'll be good to move on to the reading, which isn't as easy, unfortunately.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>外<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>outside</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Toe, Evening</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">You're known to get the ailment <font color=""#0af""><b>evening</b></font> <font color=""#0af""><b>toe</b></font>, which is when your toe catches on fire after getting really, really hot (imagine this happening, ouch!). The only way to fix it is to cool your toe down, and the best way to do that is to go <font color=""#f0a""><b>outside</b></font>.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: After imagining your <font color=""#0af""><b>evening</b></font> <font color=""#0af""><b>toe</b></font> overheating, rush <font color=""#f0a""><b>outside</b></font> to fix it. It's the best way to prevent fire toe, which is way worse. In the evening it's nice and cold outside too, so feel this on your skin, and feel the cold air on your toe, which is starting to get some relief.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>分<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>part, understand, minute</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Fins, Sword</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>fins</b></font> that fell onto my <font color=""#0af""><b>sword</b></font> were sliced into two <font color=""#f0a""><b>parts</b></font>.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: The logic of this story makes a lot of sense - even in the kanji itself the fins are falling onto the sword from above. What happens to things that fall onto swords? They become more than one <font color=""#f0a""><b>part</b></font>.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>公<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>public</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Fins, Pile</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>pile</b></font> of <b><font color=""#0af"">fins</font></b> left on the ground was for anyone. It was left there for the <font color=""#f0a""><b>public</b></font>.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine someone dumping these fins, and the <font color=""#f0a""><b>public</b></font> just waiting greedily. When they're dumped, they bum rush the pile and get as many fins as they can. The public loves their fins.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>引<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>pull</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Spring, Stick</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">If you put a <font color=""#0af""><b>stick</b></font> on a <font color=""#0af""><b>spring</b></font>, and then <font color=""#f0a""><b>pull</b></font> it, what would happen?</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Go ahead and imagine the result, but be sure to <font color=""#f0a""><b>pull</b></font> on it really hard because the spring you have is thick and good quality. When you let go, what happens? Does it hit someone? Does it cause some kind of weird disaster? I'll leave that up to you - the important thing is you're pulling on the stick against the spring to do something interesting with it.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>止<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>stop</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Stop</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The radical and the kanji for <font color=""#f0a""><b>stop</b></font> are the same, so hopefully it shouldn't be any trouble for you.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: If this kanji meaning is giving you trouble, it just means you need to study your radicals more... so... do that, okay?</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>用<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>task, use</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Elephant</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>elephant</b></font> is a large animal. It's huge, and can accomplish any <font color=""#f0a""><b>task</b></font>. You are able to <font color=""#f0a""><b>use</b></font> this elephant to finish your task, as well.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Look at your elephant... now think 'what can this sucker do?' Then, look at your task list. Come up with some ridiculous tasks for it to do and imagine them out in your head. Focus on the task list as you go through. Oh, also, 'task' sounds like 'tusk' and elephants have tusks... just a little extra juice to help you to remember.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>万<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>ten thousand</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Sword, Leaf</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">He cut the <font color=""#0af""><b>leaf</b></font> with his <font color=""#0af""><b>sword</b></font> at <font color=""#f0a""><b>10,000</b></font> miles per hour (or kilometers, if you're from one of those countries).</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: When you see these two radicals, you should think, what would I do to a leaf with a sword? You'd cut it as fast as you could. At <font color=""#f0a""><b>10,000</b></font> mph.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>広<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>wide</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Pile, Mullet</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">A disgusting <font color=""#0af""><b>pile</b></font> of <font color=""#0af""><b>mullets</b></font>. But, you're intrigued, so you pick up a mullet and try it on. Unfortunately, it's way too <font color=""#f0a""><b>wide</b></font> for your head.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: When you put on the mullet, imagine it being super flappy on the sides because it's way too big. It's like there's wings on the sides, though from back to front it fits well. It's really just too <font color=""#f0a""><b>wide</b></font>.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>冬<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>winter</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Two, Winter</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">We have the <font color=""#0af""><b>winter</b></font> radical and the <font color=""#0af""><b>two</b></font> radical (though it's sort of slanted). What's two times the winter radical, if radicals are just a part of a kanji? Two times would be enough to create the entire kanji, which is also <font color=""#f0a""><b>winter</b></font>.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: You could also think, 'Winter too' instead of 'two.' Because, this kanji is in fact '<font color=""#f0a""><b>winter</b></font> too.'</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>竹<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>bamboo</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Bamboo</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>bamboo</b></font> radical and the <font color=""#f0a""><b>bamboo</b></font> kanji are exactly the same!</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Just make sure you know your radicals!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>車<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>car</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Car</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The radical <font color=""#0af""><b>car</b></font> and the kanji <font color=""#f0a""><b>car</b></font> are exactly the same.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Make sure you study your radicals... though don't do it while driving.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>央<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>center</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Big, Head</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">If a guy has a&nbsp;<font color=""#0af""><b>big head</b></font>&nbsp;you need to try to focus on the&nbsp;<font color=""#f0a""><b>center</b></font>&nbsp;of it when you meet and talk to them. You don't want to get caught with your eyes wandering all over their big head. Stare right at the center and pretend everything is normal.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Picture a big headed person. Now stare directly at the center of their face. Ah geez, their eyes are kinda far away from here. You can really only take in this dude's nose...</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>写<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>copy</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Ground, Forehead, Beggar</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>beggar</b></font> is pointing his <font color=""#0af""><b>forehead</b></font> up at you, his feet trapped in the <font color=""#0af""><b>ground</b></font>. What diabolical scheme are you planning with this poor beggar you trapped? Turns out, you're planning to <font color=""#f0a""><b>copy</b></font> him to have your own version of him.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: You can imagine the whole story - him walking along, you setting a trap... and then whamo! You catch him. Then, come up with some crazy way / invention you're going to copy him. Are you cloning? Are you just taking his skin? Are you removing his forehead to grab his brain? Up to you - just make sure you make it ridiculous enough to remember.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>仕<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>doing</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Leader, Samurai</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>leader</b></font> <font color=""#0af""><b>samurai</b></font> didn't become leader by sitting around not taking action. He got to where he is by <font color=""#f0a""><b>doing</b></font>.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Think through all the <font color=""#f0a""><b>doing</b></font> he may have done in this past. Not all of it was easy, but it was actions, not sitting that moved him forward in life... just like with you! Learning kanji is about action, not about waiting. Learn a bit every day and good things will happen.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>耳<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>ear</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Ear</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#0af""><b>ear</b></font> radical and <font color=""#f0a""><b>ear</b></font> kanji are the same in looks as well as meaning.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Study those radicals hard to make sure you know your kanji as well!</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>早<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>early, fast</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Cross, Sun</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">When the <font color=""#0af""><b>sun</b></font> is over the <font color=""#0af""><b>cross</b></font> it's time to go to church... which is so darn <font color=""#f0a""><b>early</b></font>.<br>This kanji can also mean <font color=""#f0a""><b>fast</b></font> too. Because, if you're early, you're probably pretty fast.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine the sun coming up slowly, over the horizon. It then lines up with the cross, and at that moment, your alarm goes off, waking you up. You check the alarm clock, and instead of displaying the time, it just says <font color=""#f0a""><b>early</b></font> on it, flashing in big red letters.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>気<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>energy, spirit</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Treasure, Energy</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">You're looking for a <font color=""#0af""><b>treasure</b></font>, but no normal treasure... a treasure that's a stash of <font color=""#0af""><b>energy</b></font>. Not gold, money, or anything like that. Imagine yourself finding it, and opening up a treasure chest. Out bursts a <font color=""#f0a""><b>spirit</b></font> ball of <font color=""#f0a""><b>energy</b></font> like you've never seen.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Try to touch the <font color=""#f0a""><b>energy</b></font> <font color=""#f0a""><b>spirit</b></font>, it's pretty amazing. Is it solid? Does it shock you? What does it feel like? Be sure to imagine it out.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>平<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>flat, peace</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Antenna, Horns</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">You put <font color=""#0af""><b>horns</b></font> on your <font color=""#0af""><b>antenna</b></font>&nbsp;to make your TV signal better. Instead, the horns combined with the antenna create something that attracts all horned animals for miles around. The animals all come running, knock everything over (including your house) causing everything to be <font color=""#f0a""><b>flat</b></font>.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine yourself, your house, your cat, your everything... all completely <font color=""#f0a""><b>flat</b></font>... ridiculously so (the more ridiculous the better).<br>This kanji also means <font color=""#f0a""><b>peace</b></font>. Why? Because flat things are nice and peaceful. They aren't bumpy. They aren't uneven. They're just flat. So much <font color=""#f0a""><b>peace</b></font> in flatness.</i></span><p> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>花<br><br><br><br></div>  Meaning:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>flower</b></font></span><p>  <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Spoon, Leader, Flowers</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Meaning Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">A <font color=""#0af""><b>leader</b></font> with a <font color=""#0af""><b>spoon</b></font> is planting <font color=""#0af""><b>flowers</b></font> so that one day this place may be full of beautiful <font color=""#f0a""><b>flower</b></font>s.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: It's kind of weird that the flowers radical is only a part of the flower kanji, but you'll make do. Just focus on the fact that the leader is planting all these flowers for a bigger picture thing (that's what leaders do).
