"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>七<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>seven</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>しち</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">なな</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Seven</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">You know this kanji means <font color=""#f0a""><b>Seven</b></font>, so let's use that to remember the reading too. <font color=""#f0a""><b>Seven</b></font> is a lucky number, usually, but this time it wasn't so good. <br><font color=""#f0a""><b>Seven</b></font> percent is all she got on her test after <font><b>she chea</b></font>ted (しち) on it.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: How unbelievable is it that someone got <font color=""#f0a""><b>seven</b></font> percent on a test, especially if you try to cheat? Imagine the girl you loathe the most from school, and imagine her cheating on the test (it's important it's a girl, because of the 'she' part in <font><b>she chea</b></font>ted (しち). Then, imagine your happiness when she's super upset about getting seven percent on it. Serves her right, obviously.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>十<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>ten</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>じゅう</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">とお</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Cross</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">So, now that you have the <font color=""#f0a""><b>Ten</b></font> Commandments in your head, think 'who held up these Ten Commandments?' Why it was Moses, who was a <font><b>Jew</b></font> (じゅう).</span></span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: See how the progression of everything works? If you know the radicals, you can remember the meaning. If you know the meaning, you can remember the reading. It's all about connecting these things to each other in your head, because the more connections you have, the more likely you are to remember! It's just how the brain works.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>三<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>three</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>さん</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">み</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Ground, Two</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">I'm going to count to <font color=""#f0a""><b>three</b></font>, then I'm going to whack you with these three sticks, <font><b>son</b></font> (さん).</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: I think a Southern accent goes well with this meaning mnemonic. You'll want to imagine that you're a boy and your dad has three sticks, ready for some thwacking. Feel a little afraid by this, and sad about three times the pain. The more emotions you can input (like fear) into this mnemonic, the more likely you are to remember it!</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>二<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>two</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>に</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">ふた</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Two</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Think of all the things you have <font color=""#f0a""><b>Two</b></font> of. What is the most important? Some would say eyes, some would say ears. I would say the <font><b>knee</b></font> (に) because if you didn't have them, it'd be really hard to go up stairs.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine yourself without two knees, and see what it would be like. What would give you trouble? What couldn't you do? Just imagining this for a minute or two will help you to remember the reading of this kanji more effectively.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>女<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>woman</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>じょ</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">おんな,&nbsp;め</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Woman</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">When you imagine this woman, she has a <font><b>jo</b></font> (じょ) weapon. She's standing in a battle stance, and yelling ""I'm the mighty jo fighter woman!""</span></span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Be sure to think ""Huh, what a weird lady... Wait, she's gonna hit me with that jo of hers, crap!!""</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>又<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>again</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">また　(kun)</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>また</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Stool</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">So, she's really pregnant, and carrying a stool, sitting on it again and <font color=""#f0a""><b>again</b></font>. Where are you two going? Where would a super preggers person go? Well, she needs to go to the <font><b>mata</b></font>nity (また) store to get new clothes for her giant baby stomach.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: I know 'mata' and 'maternity' are a bit of a stretch, but the goal is to get you to the memory of また in your head, so they don't necessarily need to be exactly the same. If this can get you to the correct memory in your head, then it does the right thing, and that's good. So, make that your goal and you'll probably remember the reading for this kanji!</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>玉<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>ball</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">たま(ぎょく)</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>たま</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Drop, King</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Think of someone curled up in a ball. It is someone you know / someone famous named “Tom” (たま).</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: So, who's in a ball? Which 'Tom' did you choose?</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>本<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>book, origin, real, main</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>ほん</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">もと</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Real</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text""><font color=""#f0a""><b>Books</b></font> are one of the best ways to <font><b>hone</b></font> (ほん) your intellect, you know?</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: A bit weak in the memory department, I know, but run it through your mind a few times. Luckily, you’ll see this on’yomi so much it’ll end up being hard not remembering it, good memory technique or not.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>子<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>child</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>し,&nbsp;</b>す</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">こ</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Child</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">To remember the sounds し and す we'll use these mnemonics:&nbsp;<br>There's a <font color=""#f0a""><b>child</b></font>. He's walking around, having a good time. Then, all of a sudden out of nowhere, Charlie <font><b>Shee</b></font>n (し) jumps out and grabs the child, then runs away with him.&nbsp;That child's parents are definitely going to <b>sue</b> (す) Charlie <b>Shee</b>n (し).</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: You give chase after him - make sure you zero in on the child, thinking about how you need to save said child. The child is what's important here, because that's the kanji you're learning. Oh, and Charlie Sheen as well, since you have to remember the reading, too.  Of course, think about the ridiculousness of the situation. First of all, it's Charlie Sheen. Second of all, he's abducting a child. Third, if he gets away, he's totally getting sued. That's crazy... well... maybe not that crazy.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>丸<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>circle</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">まる (がん)</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>まる</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Drop, Nine</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Do you know about the adorable cat Maru? If not, you should <a href=""https://youtu.be/z_AbfPXTKms"">check it out</a>. May seem like a distraction, but if you come back knowing the reading for this kanji, then it's totally worth while.<br>When you think about a circle, think about <font><b>Maru</b></font> all rolled up in a little circle, being super adorable. Don't tell me it doesn't melt your heart just thinking about it.Alternatively, you could also look at this kanji and think of Maru inside of a box, with her little tail sticking out of it. Whatever works best for you, just get yourself to 'Maru.'</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Obviously if you 'don't know this reading' well enough, you should watch some more Maru videos. I'll understand... just make sure you come back someday, okay?</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>正<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>correct</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>せい, しょう</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">ただ,&nbsp;まさ</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Ground, Stop</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">To remember the reading せい we use 'Hard Gay,' because he likes to say 'SEI SEI SEI!' Of course, if you don't know who this Japanese comedian is, you should check him out (literally or figuratively, whatever you want to do is your own business). Here he is <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FuwoZsEHFbY"">helping out a ramen shop</a>. As you're correcting these test answers, someone grabs your pencil and throws your desk to the side. And then they start humping your leg. It's <font><b>Hard Gay</b></font> (せい). He tells you that the test you are grading is the <font><b>sho</b></font>gun's (しょう)! You can't give the shogun a bad grade, he'll have you executed!</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine Hard Gay shouting that you can't give the shogun a bad grade. Why is Hard Gay telling you this? You can't seem to figure out why, but with Hard Gay humping your leg it's hard to really concentrate on anything else.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>犬<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>dog</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">いぬ (けん)</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>いぬ</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Dog</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">You see an emu running towards you from off in the distance (strange to see an emu in these parts...). As it gets closer, you realize that it's not an emu at all, it's something that sounds the same, or similar... an <font><b>inu</b></font>!</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: There's a good chance you know the word for dog in Japanese already too. If so, you're ahead of the game. If not, do your best to learn the reading before moving on.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>夕<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>evening</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">ゆう　(せき)</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>ゆう</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Evening</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#f0a""><b>evening</b></font> is when it's time for <font><b>YOU</b></font> (ゆう).</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Think about the day, and how it's all about doing things for other people... school, work, etc. But, in the evening, you do what <font><b>you</b></font> want, nothing else. Think about what those things might be. Say out loud 'This is for YOU.'</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>出<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>exit</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>しゅつ</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">で, だ</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Mountain</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">As you're trying to <font color=""#f0a""><b>exit</b></font> this mountain range, you suddenly realize that someone is actually hunting you. What? Make sure to feel that sudden realization. It's crazy. Then, you find the exit and run towards it. Sadly, the hunter is waiting there, and he <font><b>shoots</b></font> you (しゅつ) through the leg, knocking you down.</span></span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Focus on the surprise of realizing you're being hunted while trying to find the exit to the mountain range, then focus on the next part, where you get shot. View it in your head as the hunter shooting you. Powww!</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>目<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>eye</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">め (もく)</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>め</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Eye</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Your <font color=""#f0a""><b>eyes</b></font> are important to you, right? Sadly, one of your eyes is missing right now, because a sheep grabbed it and pulled it out, and is now running away from you, yelling his sheep call.... '<font><b>Mehhhhhh</b></font> (め)!'</span></span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Of course, feel the pain of your eye being gone... and struggle to get it back. You eventually give up because the sheep is too fast, but then you come up with an idea. What if I call out back to the sheep in its own language? Go ahead and cover one eye and start making 'MEHHH' noises to see if you can get the sheep to come back to you and give you your eye. It's up to you whether it works or not, but be sure to feel frustrated by its reaction, or happy by it. Either one works.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>了<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>finish</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>りょう</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">-</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Barb</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">How does the fish lure maker test his newly <font color=""#f0a""><b>finish</b></font>ed lure out? The one he just finished? He gets in a <font><b>row</b></font> (りょう) boat and rows out into the sea.</span></span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Make him think that he can’t just use his new lure on the side of the lake / ocean / whatever. He has to get out there, but unfortunately all he has is a crappy row boat. Imagine the row boat being terrible, leaky, and dangerous, which is why you’re surprised when he goes for it. That’s a terrible row boat to use! If you do this, you'll focus your mind on the rowboat part of things, which will help you to remember the reading of this kanji.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>火<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>fire</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>か</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">ひ,&nbsp;ほ</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Fire</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Whenever we need to remember か, we use the word <font><b>car</b></font>.<br>For this kanji, when we think <font color=""#f0a""><b>fire</b></font>, we ought to think of something on fire. What is it on fire? It's obviously your very own <font><b>car</b></font> (か)! Oh Goddd NOOO!</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Oh no... Oh no!! If you don't have a <font><b>car</b></font>, imagine what it'd feel like if your car just exploded and burned down. If you do have a car, imagine your own car in this situation. It should be a terrible feeling, if you imagine it well enough. So, when you think <font color=""#f0a""><b>fire</b></font>, remember the fear you had when your car was given to the flames. Now you have to walk everywhere, sad :(</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>五<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>five</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>ご</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">いつ</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Five</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">What do you have <font color=""#f0a""><b>five</b></font> of? The thing that comes to most people's minds is fingers (or toes). With these five fingers, you can do anything. Most notably, though, you can play the game '<font><b>go</b></font>' (ご)- a game popular strategy board game in Japan.</span></span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: When you think of your five fingers, imagine yourself playing the game go. If you don't know the game, look it up and watch some videos - you'll be able to imagine yourself playing it enough to remember the reading if you do. Focus on the hands while watching. See what the players do with their five fingers.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>四<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>four</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">よん　(し)</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>よん, よ</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Mouth, Legs</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Despite how amazing this feat you just completed is, the audience watching you is really bored. '<font><b>Yawn</b></font>' (よん) they say, politely covering their mouth.</span></span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Try to be a little upset about this. You did something crazy, but nobody is reacting. They are bored? What the heck? Zoom your imagination in on their yawns, especially. How can they be that tired by your four-sides trick?</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>才<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>genius</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>さい</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">-</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Cross, Slide</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Who do you know who's a <font color=""#f0a""><b>genius</b></font>? You don't even have to know them personally. Just think of them, and *<font><b>sigh</b></font>* (さい) when you do. Ugh, look at that genius over there. *Sigh*</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: The important part for remembering this kanji's reading is the feeling. You're so exasperated by how <font color=""#f0a""><b>genius</b></font> this person is, and how jealous you are about it. Do the <font><b>sigh</b></font> for real, too, if it will help. Just be sure to have that sighing feeling when you think about this person. The more realistic the (imagined) feeling, the more likely you are to remember this kanji's reading, too!</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>手<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>hand</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">て　(しゅ)</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>て</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Hand</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">To remember the reading て we will use the word 'Television.' You have great hands. Go ahead and look at them. OH MY GOD. You have little <font><b>te</b></font>levisions (て) on your hands. They are playing the dumbest show you can think of, too, both hands at the same time.</span></span></span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: You try to shake your hands off, but it's no good. The televisions are stuck, and the volume won't go down. You have no idea how you got these televisions on your hands. All you know is that you want them off right this instant.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>天<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>heaven</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>てん</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">あま</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Heaven</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text""><font color=""#f0a""><b>Heaven</b></font>... nowadays, people aren't all that good. Things have gotten bad. That's why the acceptance rate to get into heaven is only <font><b>ten</b></font> (てん) percent!</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine yourself in line to get into heaven. You're super worried, because you're not sure if you'll get in. You heard there was a one in <font><b>ten</b></font> chance... those aren't good odds. Feel nervous in your imagination. Feel worried. Feel the pressure as you get closer and closer to the gate... will you make it?? Ten percent!</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>刀<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>sword</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>とう</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">かたな</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Sword</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">So now you have this sweet <font color=""#f0a""><b>katana</b></font> in your hands and you're swinging it around like an idiot. Feel free to make 'whooshing' noises as you swing it around. To become a master katana wielder, you decide to travel to <font><b>To</b></font>kyo (とう). Tokyo has the best katana schools in the world, so it makes sense to travel to Tokyo.</span></span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine yourself trying to travel to Tokyo with your katana. Airport security is not happy with you trying to take a katana on the plane, so you get a full cavity search. How awful.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>王<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>king</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>おう</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">-</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">King</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text""><font><b>Oh</b></font> (おう) Great KING… Please don’t kill me… <font><b>Oh</b></font> Great KING.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Unfortunately, there isn’t a really good way to learn this one using mnemonics, just because the “oh” sound is so common. If you can get used to thinking “Oh King” as something natural when it comes to thinking of the word “king” you should be alright. I’m not saying it’ll be totally easy, but try and think “king” then think “oh king” then “king” then “oh king” a few times (or more) and it should create a connection strong enough to help you remember the on’yomi. If that doesn’t work, there’s always common vocab – and luckily there’s no kun’yomi to confuse you.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>左<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>left</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">ひだり (さ)</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>ひだり</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Construction, Narwhal</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">This is a long reading to learn compared to normal (because this kanji primarily uses kun'yomi for its reading).  Imagine all the construction workers with a funny accent. Whenever they walk by, they say ""Hi Da'ri"" (ひだり) which is supposed to be ""Hi There,"" or ""Hi Dearie."" You're not sure which, but he's definitely saying ""Hidari"" at you.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: I don't know what country these people are from, but imagine the phrase in a silly way in order to help your self to remember it.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>中<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>middle, inside</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>ちゅう</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">なか</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Middle</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">To remember the reading for this kanji, we use the word <font><b>chew</b></font>bacca to pull up ちゅう in our memory. <br>If you remember back to the radical 中, the <font color=""#f0a""><b>middle</b></font> of your mouth was stabbed with a stick. You look up to see who did it. There stands <font><b>Chew</b></font>bacca over you, doing his Chewbacca yell. He has another stick too, and this time he plants it right in the middle of your head.</span></span></span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine the fear and shock you'd feel after finding out it was Chewbacca who stabbed the middle of your mouth (and head). Give him a touch and smell too - it'll help you to remember this reading.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>月<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>moon</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>げつ, がつ</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">つき</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Moon</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Since げつ and がつ are quite similar, we'll use one mnemonic to cover both of them. I expect your experience learning Japanese throughout the future will help you to memorize and differentiate between the two. When the moon goes down and goes away, everyone in the world <font><b>gets</b></font> (げつ) up, because that means it's going to be daytime soon!</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: This one might not be as memorable at first, but if you think of the moon, and think about what people do when the moon is up, you'll come to sleeping. Then naturally you can think about what happens when the moon goes down... people <font><b>gets</b></font> up!</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>々<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>repeater</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">のま</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>のま</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Drop, Enclosure</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">In Japanese, this symbol is often called the のま because it looks like the katakana characters ノ and マ put together. If you know katakana then this will be easy to read. If you don't, think of it this way: Your mom is the <font color=""#f0a""><b>repeater</b></font>. She is trying to force feed you over and over again until you explode (literally). You keep yelling '<font><b>No ma</b></font>!' (のま) but she doesn't stop. She's on a repeating track, never stopping, repeating forever.</span></span></span></span></span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: If you feel like you're so full you're about to burst, and if you imagine your mom doing this to you (how could you, ma?) you should be able to remember the reading of this kanji. That being said, the reading is mostly only useful in the event that you have to identify a 々 - otherwise, you won't see it much.<br></span></i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>田<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>rice paddy</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">た (でん)</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>た</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Rice Paddy</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">To remember the reading た, we use the word 'taco.'<br>You're in the rice field... but when you lean down to examine the rice more closely, you see that it's not rice that's growing, it's a bunch of little <font><b>ta</b></font>cos, blossoming out of the ground.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Smell the tacos. Touch the tacos. Taste the tacos. This is definitely a very strange rice field.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>右<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>right</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">みぎ　(う, ゆう)</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>みぎ</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Mouth, Narwhal</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">This far-<font color=""#f0a""><b>right</b></font> narwhal group is getting militaristic, too. They're buying <font><b>MIG</b></font> (みぎ) fighter jets from the Russians to protect their Narwhal Friends.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: See lines and lines of MIGS on the ice where the Narwhal's live. I hope you have a little fear of this. They are scary, these jets.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>六<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>six</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>ろく</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">む</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Fins, Lid</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Whenever we need to remember the reading ろく we just use the word <font><b>rock</b></font>. <br>So, think about the devil and the devil's number. What is often associated with those things? Why, <font><b>rock</b></font> (ろく) and roll is. Imagine the lid-head fin-legged beast suddenly blasting out rock music in the middle of his destructive mayhem.</span></span></span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Sing along with the monster, if it helps you to remember the reading of this kanji.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>小<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>small</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>しょう</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">ちい, こ,&nbsp;お</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Small</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">This <font color=""#f0a""><b>small</b></font> kanji would be a terrible gift to give to the <font><b>sho</b></font>gun. This is the shogun's least favorite kanji since it's so small. The shogun's wife really likes it though, so the shogun gives it to her.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine something really really small... so small you can barely even see it. That thing is this kanji. As such, the <font><b>sho</b></font>gun really dislikes it since it doesn't look powerful. The shogun's wife thinks it's super cute though. Imagine the shogun's wife giggling and squealing over how cute it is.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>土<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>soil</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>ど,&nbsp;</b>と</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">つち</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Grave</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">To remember the reading ど, we will use the word 'dog'.<br>As you're burying this important thing with <font color=""#f0a""><b>soil</b></font>, a <font><b>do</b></font>g (ど) runs up and starts unburying it, very frantically. You try to stop it, but it snarls and snaps at you and tries to get you to back up. Turns out, the dog keeps digging past your buried object, and unburies a ghost dog, which jumps out and takes over your body. Feel what a dog feels, because you've just been taken over by a dead dog.</span></span></span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Make sure you remember all the mnemonics in order as sort of a progression of one story. They connect to each other because it's easier to remember things that connect / continue. So if you remember the pieces as a whole you're more likely to remember all the things you need to remember!</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>立<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>stand</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>りつ</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">た</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Stand</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Think of someone who has to <font color=""#f0a""><b>stand</b></font> up straight for you. These people are pros in hospitality. These are the doormen at the <font><b>Ritz</b></font> (りつ).</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine the doormen being extra straight… too straight in their standing. On their uniform is “The Ritz” written in fine lettering, and as you walk past them, they stand up straight and say “Welcome to the Ritz!” Whatever you do, while you’re thinking about it, make sure you think about how they stand up so straight, and associate it with these doormen, who work, specifically, at the Ritz. If you effectively imagine all this, you should be able to remember this on’yomi. Go through it like it’s a movie in your head!</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>石<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>stone</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">いし (せき)</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>いし</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Stone</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">You throw a <font color=""#f0a""><b>stone</b></font> through a window... that was surprisingly <font><b>easy</b></font> (いし).</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Reading's a bit of a stretch, but the goal is to get you to the correct reading, so do your best to make sure it does just that!</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>丁<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>street, ward</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>ちょう,&nbsp;</b>てい</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">-</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Nail</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Who is spreading these nails on the street? That is Mrs. <font><b>Chou</b></font> (ちょう), who will be popping up from time to time in the future as well (so be sure to get a good image of her in your head).</span></span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Might be sort of racist, but we gotta do this for memory's sake, right? Mrs. Chou is an evil little Asian lady. She hates everyone and does bad things to others for her enjoyment. Her laugh even sounds like her name. Imagine her laughing, saying 'Chou chou chou chou,' she says while spreading nails all over the street. She's like some evil Asian Santa Claus, or something.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>日<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>sun, day</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>にち, じつ</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">ひ, か,&nbsp;び</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Sun</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">There are so many on'yomi for this kanji, but since this kanji is so important and common, you'll end up learning them all eventually whether you want to or not. For now, you're only going to have to learn one of the readings, and that one is にち. <br>The <font color=""#f0a""><b>sun</b></font> is so hot. It focused its rays to take out one man... and that man is Friedrich <font><b>Nietzsche</b></font> (にち), famous philosopher. He philosophized one too many things about the sun, so the sun decided it was time he paid.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: This reading will be easier to remember if you know of Friedrich Nietzsche... so do your research and learn about him if you don't. He's a pretty historical dude. Imagine the sun totally pissed off, too. It makes a grunting noise as it builds up a sun beam to blast him off the face of the earth.<br>Also note that there's another reading worth learning as well: じつ. The reading can be remembered by thinking '<font><b>Gee! Two</b></font> readings?' Because, seriously, two readings? Too many...</span></i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>千<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>thousand</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>せん</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">ち</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Thousand</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Remember the thousand crosses you got stuck under while learning the radical 千? You're still under it. Then, suddenly, someone pops his head over you and says 'hey, I'll save you... but only for a <font color=""#f0a""><b>thousand</b></font> <font><b>cen</b></font>ts (せん). Go ahead and try to calculate what that would come out to. It's not that expensive, actually</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: But, the problem is even though you have a <font color=""#f0a""><b>thousand</b></font> <font><b>cen</b></font>ts in your pocket, you can't get them out. You're stuck under all these crosses. So, your savior just shrugs and runs off, he won't help you anymore. Feel the desperateness of the situation to help yourself remember the kanji better. Hear the coins falling on the ground.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>木<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>tree, wood</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>もく</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">き,&nbsp;こ</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Tree</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">You’re walking through the trees, looking at them. They look ominous. Then, your foot gets stuck in the <font><b>muck</b></font> (もく) and you try to pull your leg out, but can’t. Then the trees next to you beginning to <font><b>mock</b></font> you. Even the mocking birds mock you. It’s terrible. It’s painful. You’re being mocked while you’re stuck in the muck.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Feel the shame, feel the irritation. Make yourself want to break free just so you can go attack those dumb trees making fun of you and <font><b>mock</b></font>ing you.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>水<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>water</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>すい</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">みず</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Water</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Imagine a lake (i.e. a a whole bunch of <font color=""#f0a""><b>water</b></font>). When you think of water, you should try to think of this beautiful lake. It’s sunny, the trees smell nice (imagine a tree smell if you can – the more senses you use the better!) and on that tree there is an awesome tire <font><b>swi</b></font>ng (すい). You get onto the tire swing and you swinging back and forth. The water is right in front of you, and you are able to use the swing to throw yourself into the water. It’s a lot colder than you expected, and you come back to the surface, gasping for breath. The water gets into your mouth and you taste it. How strange, it’s very, very <font><b>swee</b></font>t. Imagine the sweetness of the water and how weird it is (really really sweet, this water is).</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: I know that was a long one, but try to imagine all the different bits. Try to feel the feelings (cold, smell, etc) too. The more you create in this fake memory (which you’re using to remember and associate water with すい (swing)) the more likely you are to end up remembering enough to make it happen. Especially when it comes to the senses part, the more vividly you imagined it, the more likely you are to remember the on’yomi.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>白<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>white</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>はく</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">しろ,&nbsp;しら</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">White</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#f0a""><b>white</b></font> team was the first to be able to <font><b>hack</b></font> (はく) the <font color=""#f0a""><b>white</b></font> iPhone.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine two teams (black and <font color=""#f0a""><b>white</b></font>), wearing their team colors, working really hard on hacking the iPhone. It is a huge contest, and people are watching with a lot of tensions, to see who will hack the <font color=""#f0a""><b>white</b></font> iPhone first. Feel that tension, and see the colors separating them so vividly. The colors are important, and the excitement of the winner holding up the <font><b>hack</b></font>ed iPhone is too.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>文<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>writing</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>ぶん, もん</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">-</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Doll</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">This is one of the unfortunate situations where the kanji has multiple important readings to learn... <br>The doll's <font color=""#f0a""><b>writing</b></font> states a couple of demands. First, the doll demands that you give her more bread <font><b>bun</b>s</font> (ぶん). Second, she demands you stop calling her a <font><b>mon</b></font>ster. She does not appreciate this. She is a little girl.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Make sure you read these demands out slowly in your mind. Think about each demand she has, and think about how ridiculous they are. First of all, dolls don't eat buns. Second, she's totally a monster. You better make a decision, though, and act it out in your head. Dolls don't like to be kept waiting.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>円<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>yen, round</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>えん</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">まる</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Lid, Head</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">What does the word <font color=""#f0a""><b>yen</b></font> sound like? It sounds like えん. Why? because back in the day, Japanese used to have a 'ye' sound, but now it doesn't. Instead, it's an 'e' sound, which is why yen = えん. Alternatively, you can pull one of these yen coins out of this guy's head and examine it closely. Upon inspection, you find out they're knockoffs. They're not yen. They're <font><b>En</b></font> (えん)!</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Feel disappointed that this huge money stash is worthless. En are not as good as yen, that's for sure.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>矢<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>arrow</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">や (し)</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>や</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Arrow</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">To remember the reading や we use the word “Yankees” (like the evil baseball team, go M’s!).<br>What is this arrow doing? It’s following around all the <font><b>Ya</b></font>nkee (や) baseball players, stalking them, waiting to make its move (I’ll let you decide what it’s “move” is).</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine the arrow as a human-sized living thing with legs, arms, and clothes, though. Strangely, it’s able to walk around even though its an arrow. It has some kind of agenda. Make it a bit evil, if you can. What a strange thing…</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>市<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>city</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>し</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">いち</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Lid, Two Face</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Batman is the protector of this <b><font color=""#f0a"">city</font></b> but you can't seem to find him. Someone has to stop Two-face, right? You search and search and oh no, there he is. It's Batman but his secret identity is... Charlie <b>Shee</b>n! He looks deeply into your eyes and you know your city will be safe. He's got this.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: You walk up to Charlie Sheen and realize you should have known all along. Of course no one loves your city as much as he does.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>牛<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>cow</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>ぎゅう</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">うし</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Cow</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Have you ever heard of わ<font><b>ぎゅう</b></font> beef? That ぎゅう is this ぎゅう.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: I hope you know what わぎゅう beef is, otherwise this will be a difficult one to learn.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>切<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>cut</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>せつ</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">き</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Seven, Sword</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Because having seven swords for yourself is too much, you decide to take the swords and divide them up amongst pairs of people. You <b><font color=""#f0a"">cut</font></b> them into pairs, and give <b>sets</b> (せつ) to everyone who needs them in the village.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Just make sure you think about how you need to give them away in <font><b>sets</b></font>, and not anything else. This is the most important thing to think about in your head as you're trying to establish the mnemonic for your kanji reading memory. It's gotta be sets.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>方<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>direction, way</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">かた　(ほう)</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>かた</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Direction</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">You need <font color=""#f0a""><b>direction</b></font>, but you don't know how to get it. So, you decide to choose via some way that would be somewhat random. You find a hedge <font><b>cutter</b></font> (かた) on the ground, and throw it up into the air. You'll go in the direction in which it falls. Imagine it coming down almost hitting you in the face too, how that would have hurt!</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Feel the <font><b>cutter</b></font> in your hand. Look at the tip of it... think about the possibilities that one side of the cutter will cause it to favor one direction over another. Wonder if that's really random, or not. Feel the weight of it as you throw it in the air. Whatever you do, just know that it's a cutter, and not any other tool.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>戸<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>door</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">と　(こ)</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>と</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Door</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">You open the <font color=""#f0a""><b>door</b></font> and immediately get it closed back on your <font><b>toe</b></font> (と), literally causing your toe to explode.&nbsp;</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Feel the pain of your toe going away. Think about the other side of the <font color=""#f0a""><b>door</b></font>, where your <font><b>toe</b></font> is probably rolling around after it blasted off your foot.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>太<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>fat</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>たい,&nbsp;た</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">ふと</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Big, Drop</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">This poor <font color=""#f0a""><b>fat</b></font> guy has trouble with a lot of things. One of the things he has the most trouble with is tying a <font><b>tie</b></font> (たい).</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine him trying to tie the <font><b>tie</b></font> but he can't lift his hands around to do it. You have to help him out. Another thing that might help you to remember this kanji's reading is that it's the same reading as 大 (or, one of the same readings). Similar kanji often have similar readings, which is a good thing to know when you have to guess (it's true with this one, anyways!).</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>父<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>father</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">ちち　(ふ)</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>ちち</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Father</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Imagine your father is <font><b>Cheech</b></font> (ちち) from Cheech and Chong.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Hopefully you know who they are. If not, think about your father laughing like this: ちちちちちちちち〜！</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>少<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>few, a little</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>しょう</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">すこ</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Slide, Small</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Why is there <font color=""#f0a""><b>a little</b></font> traffic jam on the slide? Because the <font><b>sho</b></font>gun (しょう) is using the slide, causing everyone to stop and watch, even though there are people backed up behind him. How inconsiderate.</span></span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine this in your head. A traffic jam on the slide, all because the shogun is using it. Picture some caution tape, orange cones, and Japanese secret service members all making sure no one gets close to the shogun while he slides.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>友<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>friend</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>ゆう</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">とも</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Narwhal, Stool</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text""><font><b>You</b></font> (ゆう) are my friend, Narwhal prince, you say. 'Only <font><b>you</b></font>.'</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: To remember this reading, you'll have to focus in on the ゆう part. It's only <font><b>you</b></font>, narwhal friend. Nobody else.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>毛<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>fur, hair</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>もう</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">け</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Fur</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">With <font color=""#f0a""><b>fur</b></font>, wisp your imagination to a land where there are stalks of fur all around, just like a big tall grassy field (except instead of grass, it’s fur). You’re surrounded by the black fur, the wind is blowing. Imagine yourself touching the long fur and smelling it. What does it feel / smell like? Now it’s time to get rid of it. There’s just too much <font color=""#f0a""><b>hair</b></font>! To get rid of it, you’ll need to <font><b>mow</b></font> (もう) it down with a lawn mower. Imagine yourself starting up the lawn mower, and taking it around, mowing down the hair. Hear the sound of the mower in your head (they’re loud and distinct). The important thing is to imagine yourself mowing everything. Key is to think “fur → In the fur → getting rid of the fur → mow the fur,” in that order. That’ll get you to mow, which will help you to remember the on’yomi.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Smell the <font color=""#f0a""><b>fur</b></font> as you <font><b>mow</b></font> it down. Feel it flying everywhere. It's giant, so it must be pretty intense. Make it more intense to help yourself to remember the reading of this kanji better.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>半<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>half</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>はん</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">なか</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Antenna, Triceratops</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">One of the channels you do get has Star Wars on it, though. Feel a little happy about that. It's the scene with the carbonite and Han Solo. <font color=""#f0a""><b>Half</b></font> of <font><b>Han</b></font>'s body is sticking out of the carbonite.&nbsp;</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Hopefully you’ve seen Star Wars, and you know what Han Solo looks like coming out of the carbonite. Half of him is sticking out in that expression everyone knows and loves. It's a very vivid picture, and focusing on it should help you to memorize the reading better as well. 'Half of Han Solo.'</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>心<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>heart</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>しん</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">こころ</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Heart</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The <font color=""#f0a""><b>heart</b></font>, where is it stored in your body? Most people thought it was in the chest, but in reality, your <font color=""#f0a""><b>heart</b></font> is stored in your <font><b>shin</b></font> (しん).</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: This is when I start kicking you in the shin and you imagine feeling the pain of getting kicked there. As I kick you in the shin, you grab your chest... all this stress is giving you a heart attack (though your shin hurts a ton too).</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>内<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>inside</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>ない</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">うち</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Person, Head</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">You know this kanji means inside, so you can keep thinking about the person that’s inside you, running around. You finally discover him, and try to take him out, but before you can, he pulls out a <font><b>kni</b></font>fe (ない) and threatens to cut you if you do anything irrational.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine him holding the knife out, threatening to stab your brain. You’re in a conundrum here. If you don’t take him out, you’re in trouble, but if you do try to take him out, he might stab you in the brain with his knife. Try to think a way around this situation, focusing mainly on his knife.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>生<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>life</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>せい,&nbsp;しょう</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">い, う, なま,&nbsp;は, き</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Life</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Whenever we need to remember せい, we use the character 'Hard Gay' because he always says 'SEI SEI SEI!'<br>If anyone out there is full of <font color=""#f0a""><b>life</b></font>, it's got to be Hard Gay, especially when he's shouting '<font><b>Sei</b></font> (せい), sei, sei!' He's so excited about everything, and has a great time with other people. What an awesome life.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: If you don't know Hard Gay, you should definitely search Hard Gay on YouTube... I promise it won't be as bad as it sounds... and, it'll help you to learn your kanji better, strangely. Just be sure to come back here when you're done, because you have kanji to study!</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>久<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>long time</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">ひさ　(きゅう,&nbsp;く)</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>ひさ</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Raptor Cage</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Turns out, the person telling you is a big idiot. It's Jar Jar Binks. '<font><b>Heesa</b></font> (ひさ) very scary raptor!' he yells before running off.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Add a few more instances of Jar Jar saying 'Heesa' instead of 'He's a' in your mind.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>台<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>machine</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>だい,&nbsp;</b>たい</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">-</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Mouth, Pile</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Finally, you're in luck. The police and emergency services have found you and saved you (feel the relief of that!). But, because you're full of cars and microwave ovens, they can't fit you in the ambulance (feel the disappointment at that). They do everything they can to get you out of there and back to the hospital but you're too big. You just <font><b>die</b></font> (だい) right there while they try to shove you into various emergency vehicles.</span></span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine the conversation the emergency people would have... 'we can fit him in...' 'If we don't get him in, he'll die!' 'Well, I guess he's going to die then...' Wait, they're going to let me die???</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>母<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>mother</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">はは　(ぼ)</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>はは</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Drawer</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Whenever your <font color=""#f0a""><b>mother</b></font> tells you to put away your own clothes in your <font color=""#0af""><b>drawer</b></font> though, you just laugh. '<font><b>Ha ha</b></font>!' you say.</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: <font><b>HAHA</b></font> this!! your <font color=""#f0a""><b>mother</b></font> might reply, slapping you across the head.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>午<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>noon</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>ご</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">-</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Slide, Antenna</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">Because you can't watch TV at <font color=""#f0a""><b>noon</b></font>, you find you have to watch TV at another time. That time is Five (<font><b>ご</span></b></font>) o'clock, and it's a TV show about the game of <font><b>go</b></font> (ご).</span></span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: It's so boring, though, and you hate it. Feel the boredom and the frustration of having to watch a stupid show about go when you could be watching a show about slides at noon. I guess go will have to do :(</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>北<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>north</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>ほく</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">きた</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Spoon, Nailbat</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">You find Santa and hit him with your nailbat and spoon. Because you hit him in the stomach, he <font><b>hock</b></font>s (ほく) up an elf.</span></span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: The elf falls out of Santa's mouth all slimy and covered with nasty Santa-throat things. Then, Santa <font><b>hock</b></font>s up a hairball. Too much beard grooming, I guess.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>今<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>now</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>こん</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">いま</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Ra, Hat</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">When we need to remember the reading こん, we'll use the word 'Condor.' When Ra gets his hat taken off his head, the servant runs off with it to put it away someplace safe. Suddenly, a <font><b>Con</b></font>dor (こん) swoops down grabbing the hat, tearing it away from the servant. Ra is pissed, and shoots the condor down, burning his hat and the condor.</span></span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine the surprise of a condor going for a hat like that, especially a god like Ra's hat. Must have been really cool for a condor to do that.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>古<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>old</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>こ</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">ふる</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Old</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">To remember the reading こ, we will use 子 (ko/child). A child is the opposite of someone really really <font color=""#f0a""><b>old</b></font>, so use this disparity to remember the reading here.</span></span></span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Imagine a really old man writing this content and next to him there is also a child. Use these two contrasting images to remember that this kanji shares the same reading as 子, <font><b>こ</b></font>.</span></i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>兄<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>older brother</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">あに (きょう)</font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>あに</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Mouth, Legs</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">The strange thing about your <font color=""#f0a""><b>older brother</b></font> is that he has odd powers... some would say powers of the force. Do you know what his name is? It's <font><b>Ani</b></font> (あに), short for Anikin... wait a sec, does that sound familiar?</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Be sure to be surprised to find out your <font color=""#f0a""><b>older brother</b></font> is actually the future Darth Vader. Now imagine your mouth-legs older brother wielding a light saber, coming at you... '<font><b>Ani</b></font>!!!' you yell... but it's no good, because mouths don't have ears.</i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>元<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>origin</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>げん,&nbsp;がん</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">もと</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Origin</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">What is your <font color=""#f0a""><b>origin</b></font>, in the grand scheme of things? What generation were you? I was <font><b>Gen</b></font>-Y (げん), for example. You might be <font><b>Gen</b></font>-X, or something else.</span></span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: Important thing is to think about your <font color=""#f0a""><b>origin</b></font> in terms of your generation, because that will help you to remember the reading of this kanji. Of course, the word 'generation' and げん have a different 'G' sound, but the goal is to get you close enough in your brain to pull out the actual memory of the correct reading, not to use the exact same sounds. If you get close enough to the spot where げん=元 is stored, you'll be able to retrieve it a lot more easily.</span></span></span></i></span><br> "
"<div class=""kanji""><br><br><br>外<br><br><br><br></div>  Reading:  "	"<span class=""title""><font color=""#f0a""><b>outside</b></font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>On'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000""><b>がい</b></font></span><br> <span class=""text""><b>Kun'yomi: </b></span> <span class=""hiragana""><font color=""#000000"">そと,&nbsp;はず</font></span><p> <span class=""text""><b>Radicals: </b></span> <span class=""text"">Toe, Evening</span><p>  <span class=""text""><b><u>Reading Mnemonic</u></b></span><br> <span class=""text"">You go <font color=""#f0a""><b>outside</b></font> (you’re not supposed to be out there at night!) and you’re accosted by a couple of guys. Then, all of a sudden, <font><b>Guy</b></font> Fawkes jumps from the roof above you and takes them out, then starts running. “Guy Fawkes!” you yell after him!</span><p> <span class=""text""><i>Hint: If you don’t know Guy Fawkes, you should do a little reading up on him to make this mnemonic make sense. Also, Anonymous People wear a Guy Fawkes mask, if that helps any.</i></span><br> "
